title: Texas Instruments
text:
Texas Instruments Incorporated (TI) is an <a href="America">America</a>n technology company headquartered in <a href="Dallas">Dallas</a>, <a href="Texas">Texas</a>, that designs and manufactures <a href="semiconductor">semiconductor</a>s and various <a href="integrated%20circuit">integrated circuit</a>s, which it sells to electronics designers and <a href="manufacturer">manufacturer</a>s globally. It is one of the top 10 semiconductor companies worldwide based on <a href="sales">sales</a> volume. The company's focus is on developing <a href="analog%20chip">analog chip</a>s and <a href="embedded%20processor">embedded processor</a>s, which account for more than 80% of its revenue. TI also produces TI <a href="Digital%20Light%20Processing">digital light processing</a> technology and education technology products including <a href="calculator">calculator</a>s, <a href="microcontroller">microcontroller</a>s, and <a href="multi-core%20processor">multi-core processor</a>s. The company holds 45,000 patents worldwide as of 2016.
Texas Instruments emerged in 1951 after a reorganization of <a href="Geophysical%20Service%20Incorporated">Geophysical Service Incorporated</a>, a company founded in 1930 that manufactured equipment for use in the seismic industry, as well as defense electronics. TI produced the world's first commercial <a href="silicon%20transistor">silicon transistor</a> in 1954, and the same year designed and manufactured the first <a href="transistor%20radio">transistor radio</a>. <a href="Jack%20Kilby">Jack Kilby</a> invented the <a href="integrated%20circuit">integrated circuit</a> in 1958 while working at TI's Central Research Labs. TI also invented the hand-held <a href="calculator">calculator</a> in 1967, and introduced the first single-chip microcontroller in 1970, which combined all the elements of computing onto one piece of silicon.
In 1987, TI invented the <a href="Digital%20Light%20Processing">digital light processing device</a> (also known as the DLP chip), which serves as the foundation for the company's award-winning DLP technology and DLP Cinema. TI released the popular <a href="TI-81">TI-81</a> calculator in 1990, which made it a leader in the graphing calculator industry. Its defense business was sold to <a href="Raytheon">Raytheon</a> in 1997; this allowed TI to strengthen its focus on digital solutions. After the acquisition of <a href="National%20Semiconductor">National Semiconductor</a> in 2011, the company had a combined portfolio of 45,000 analog products and customer design tools. In the stock market, Texas Instruments is often regarded as an indicator for the semiconductor and electronics industry as a whole, since the company sells to more than 100,000 customers.
History.
Texas Instruments was founded by <a href="Cecil%20H.%20Green">Cecil H. Green</a>, <a href="J.%20Erik%20Jonsson">J. Erik Jonsson</a>, <a href="Eugene%20McDermott">Eugene McDermott</a>, and <a href="Patrick%20E.%20Haggerty">Patrick E. Haggerty</a> in 1951. McDermott was one of the original founders of <a href="Geophysical%20Service%20Incorporated">Geophysical Service</a> Inc. (GSI) in 1930. McDermott, Green, and Jonsson were GSI employees who purchased the company in 1941. In November 1945, Patrick Haggerty was hired as general manager of the Laboratory and Manufacturing (L&M) division, which focused on electronic equipment. By 1951, the L&M division, with its defense contracts, was growing faster than GSI's geophysical division. The company was reorganized and initially renamed General Instruments Inc. Because a firm named <a href="General%20Instrument">General Instrument</a> already existed, the company was renamed Texas Instruments that same year. From 1956 to 1961, <a href="Fred%20Agnich">Fred Agnich</a> of Dallas, later a <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> member of the <a href="Texas%20House%20of%20Representatives">Texas House of Representatives</a>, was the Texas Instruments president. Geophysical Service, Inc. became a subsidiary of Texas Instruments. Early in 1988, most of GSI was sold to the <a href="Halliburton">Halliburton</a> Company.
Geophysical Service Incorporated.
In 1930, <a href="J.%20Clarence%20Karcher">J. Clarence Karcher</a> and Eugene McDermott founded Geophysical Service, an early provider of <a href="reflection%20seismology">seismic exploration</a> services to the petroleum industry. In 1939, the company reorganized as Coronado Corp, an oil company with Geophysical Service Inc (GSI), now as a subsidiary. On December 6, 1941, McDermott along with three other GSI employees, J. Erik Jonsson, Cecil H. Green, and H. B. Peacock purchased GSI. During World War II, GSI expanded its services to include <a href="electronics">electronics</a> for the <a href="United%20States%20Army">U.S. Army</a>, <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Signal%20Corps">Army Signal Corps</a>, and <a href="United%20States%20Navy">U.S. Navy</a>. In 1951, the company changed its name to Texas Instruments, spun off to build seismographs for oil explorations and with GSI becoming a wholly owned subsidiary of the new company.
An early success story for TI-GSI came in 1965 when GSI was able (under a <a href="security%20clearance">Top Secret</a> government contract) to monitor the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>'s underground <a href="nuclear%20weapon">nuclear weapon</a>s <a href="nuclear%20testing">testing</a> under the ocean in <a href="Vela%20Uniform">Vela Uniform</a>, a subset of <a href="Project%20Vela">Project Vela</a>, to verify compliance of the <a href="Partial%20Nuclear%20Test%20Ban%20Treaty">Partial Nuclear Test Ban Treaty</a>.
Texas Instruments also continued to manufacture equipment for use in the seismic industry, and GSI continued to provide seismic services. After selling (and repurchasing) GSI, TI finally sold the company to <a href="Halliburton">Halliburton</a> in 1988, after which sale GSI ceased to exist as a separate entity.
Semiconductors.
In early 1952, Texas Instruments purchased a patent license to produce germanium transistors from <a href="Western%20Electric">Western Electric</a>, the manufacturing arm of AT&T, for $25,000, beginning production by the end of the year.
On January 1, 1953, Haggerty brought <a href="Gordon%20Teal">Gordon Teal</a> to the company as a research director. Gordon brought with him his expertise in growing semiconductor crystals. Teal's first assignment was to organize what became TI's Central Research Laboratories, which Teal based on his prior experience at Bell Labs.
Among his new hires was <a href="Willis%20Adcock">Willis Adcock</a>, who joined TI early in 1953. Adcock, who like Teal was a <a href="physical%20chemist">physical chemist</a>, began leading a small research group focused on the task of fabricating grown-junction, <a href="silicon">silicon</a>, single-crystal, small-signal transistors. Adcock later became the first TI Principal Fellow.
First silicon transistor and integrated circuits.
In January 1954, <a href="Morris%20Tanenbaum">Morris Tanenbaum</a> at <a href="Bell%20Labs">Bell Labs</a> created the first workable silicon transistor. This work was reported in the spring of 1954, at the IRE off-the-record conference on solid-state devices, and was later published in the "Journal of Applied Physics". Working independently in April 1954, Gordon Teal at TI created the first commercial silicon transistor and tested it on April 14, 1954. On May 10, 1954, at the Institute of Radio Engineers National Conference on Airborne Electronics in Dayton, Ohio, Teal presented a paper: "Some Recent Developments in Silicon and Germanium Materials and Devices".
In 1954, Texas Instruments designed and manufactured the first <a href="transistor%20radio">transistor radio</a>. The <a href="Regency%20TR-1">Regency TR-1</a> used germanium transistors, as silicon transistors were much more expensive at the time. This was an effort by Haggerty to increase market demand for transistors.
<a href="Jack%20Kilby">Jack Kilby</a>, an employee at TI's Central Research Labs, invented the <a href="integrated%20circuit">integrated circuit</a> in 1958. Kilby recorded his initial ideas concerning the integrated circuit in July 1958, and successfully demonstrated the world's first working integrated circuit on September 12, 1958. Six months later, <a href="Robert%20Noyce">Robert Noyce</a> of <a href="Fairchild%20Semiconductor">Fairchild Semiconductor</a> (who went on to co-found <a href="Intel">Intel</a>) independently developed the integrated circuit with integrated interconnect, and is also considered an inventor of the integrated circuit. In 1969, Kilby was awarded the National Medal of Science, and in 1982 he was inducted into the National Inventor's Hall of Fame. Kilby also won the 2000 Nobel Prize in Physics for his part of the invention of the integrated circuit. Noyce's chip, made at Fairchild, was made of silicon, while Kilby's chip was made of <a href="germanium">germanium</a>. In 2008, TI named its new development laboratory "Kilby Labs" after Jack Kilby.
In 2011, Intel, Samsung, LG, ST-Ericsson, Huawei's HiSilicon Technologies subsidiary, Via Telecom, and three other undisclosed chipmakers licensed the C2C link specification developed by Arteris Inc. and Texas Instruments.
Standard TTL.
The <a href="7400%20series">7400 series</a> of <a href="transistor-transistor%20logic">transistor-transistor logic</a> chips, developed by Texas Instruments in the 1960s, popularized the use of integrated circuits in computer logic. The military-grade version of this was the 5400 series.
Microprocessor.
Texas Instruments invented the hand-held <a href="calculator">calculator</a> (a prototype called "<a href="Cal%20Tech%20%28calculator%29">Cal Tech</a>") in 1967 and the single-chip <a href="microcomputer">microcomputer</a> in 1971, was assigned the first patent on a single-chip <a href="microprocessor">microprocessor</a> (invented by Gary Boone) on September 4, 1973. This was disputed by Gilbert Hyatt, formerly of the Micro Computer Company, in August 1990, when he was awarded a patent superseding TI's. This was overturned on June 19, 1996, in favor of TI (note: <a href="Intel">Intel</a> is usually given credit with Texas Instruments for the almost-simultaneous invention of the microprocessor).
First speech synthesis chip.
In 1978, Texas Instruments introduced the first single-chip <a href="linear%20predictive%20coding">linear predictive coding</a> <a href="speech%20synthesizer">speech synthesizer</a>. In 1976, TI began a feasibility study of memory-intensive applications for bubble memory then being developed. They soon focused on speech applications. This resulted in the development the TMC0280 one-chip linear predictive coding speech synthesizer, which was the first time a single silicon chip had electronically replicated the human voice. This was used in several TI commercial products beginning with <a href="Speak%20%26amp%3B%20Spell%20%28toy%29">Speak & Spell</a>, which was introduced at the Summer Consumer Electronics Show in June 1978. In 2001, TI left the speech synthesis business, selling it to Sensory Inc. of Santa Clara, California.
Consumer electronics and computers.
In May 1954, Texas Instruments designed and built a prototype of the world's first <a href="transistor%20radio">transistor radio</a>, and, through a partnership with Industrial Development Engineering Associates of Indianapolis, Indiana, the 100% solid-state radio was sold to the public beginning in October of that year.
In the 1960s, company president Pat Haggerty had a team that included Jack Kilby to work on a handheld calculator project. Kilby and two other colleagues created the Cal-Tech, a three-pound battery-powered calculator that could do basic math and fit six-digit numbers on its display. This 4.25 x 6.15 x 1.75 inch calculator's processor would originate the vast majority of Texas Instruments’ revenue.
In 1973, the handheld calculator SR-10 (named after <a href="slide%20rule">slide rule</a>) and in 1974 the handheld scientific calculator <a href="TI%20SR-50">SR-50</a> were issued by TI. Both had red LED-segments numeric displays. The optical design of the SR-50 is somewhat similar to the <a href="HP-35">HP-35</a> edited by Hewlett Packard before in early 1972, but buttons for the operations "+", "–", ... are in the right of the number block and the decimal point lies between two neighboring digits.
TI continued to be active in the consumer electronics market through the 1970s and 1980s. Early on, this also included two digital clock models - one for desk and the other a bedside alarm. From this sprang what became the Time Products Division, which made LED watches. Though these LED watches enjoyed early commercial success due to excellent quality, it was short-lived due to poor battery life. LEDs were replaced with LCD watches for a short time, but these could not compete because of styling issues, excessive makes and models, and price points. The watches were manufactured in Dallas and then Lubbock, Texas. Several spin-offs of the Speak & Spell, such as the <a href="Speak%20%26amp%3B%20Read">Speak & Read</a> and <a href="Speak%20%26amp%3B%20Math">Speak & Math</a>, were introduced soon thereafter.
In 1979, TI entered the <a href="home%20computer">home computer</a> market with the <a href="Texas%20Instruments%20TI-99/4A">TI-99/4</a>, a competitor to such entries as the <a href="Apple%20II">Apple II</a>, <a href="Tandy%20Corporation">Tandy</a>/<a href="RadioShack">Radio Shack</a> <a href="TRS-80">TRS-80</a>, and the later <a href="Atari">Atari</a> <a href="Atari%208-bit%20family">400</a>/<a href="Atari%208-bit%20family">800</a> series and <a href="Commodore%20International">Commodore</a> <a href="VIC-20">VIC-20</a>. It discontinued the <a href="Texas%20Instruments%20TI-99/4A">TI-99/4A</a> (1981), the sequel to the 99/4, in late 1983 amid an intense <a href="North%20American%20video%20game%20crash%20of%201983%23A%20Savage%20Price%20War">price war</a> waged primarily against Commodore. At the 1983 Winter CES, TI showed models 99/2 and the <a href="Texas%20Instruments%20Compact%20Computer%2040">Compact Computer 40 (CC-40)</a>, the latter aimed at professional users. The <a href="Texas%20Instruments%20Professional%20Computer%20and%20Professional%20Portable%20Computer">TI Professional</a> (1983) ultimately joined the ranks of the many unsuccessful <a href="DOS">DOS</a> and <a href="x86">x86</a>-based—but <a href="PC%20compatible%23Compatibility%20issues">non-compatible</a>—competitors to the <a href="IBM%20PC">IBM PC</a> (the founders of <a href="Compaq">Compaq</a>, an early leader in PC compatibles, all came from TI). The company for years successfully made and sold PC-compatible laptops before withdrawing from the market and selling its product line to <a href="Acer%20Inc.">Acer</a> in 1998.
Defense electronics.
TI entered the <a href="defense%20%28military%29">defense</a> electronics market in 1942 with submarine detection equipment, based on the seismic exploration technology previously developed for the oil industry. The division responsible for these products was known at different times as the Laboratory & Manufacturing Division, the Apparatus Division, the Equipment Group, and the Defense Systems & Electronics Group (DSEG).
During the early 1980s, TI instituted a quality program which included <a href="Joseph%20M.%20Juran">Juran</a> training, as well as promoting <a href="statistical%20process%20control">statistical process control</a>, <a href="Taguchi%20methods">Taguchi methods</a>, and <a href="Design%20for%20Six%20Sigma">Design for Six Sigma</a>. In the late '80s, the company, along with <a href="Eastman%20Kodak">Eastman Kodak</a> and <a href="Allied%20Signal">Allied Signal</a>, began involvement with <a href="Motorola">Motorola</a>, institutionalizing Motorola's <a href="Six%20Sigma">Six Sigma</a> methodology. Motorola, which originally developed the Six Sigma methodology, began this work in 1982. In 1992, the DSEG division of Texas Instruments' quality-improvement efforts were rewarded by winning the <a href="Malcolm%20Baldrige%20National%20Quality%20Award">Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award</a> for manufacturing.
TI developed the AAA-4 <a href="infrared%20search%20and%20track">infrared search and track</a> in the late '50s and early '60s for the <a href="F-4B%20Phantom">F-4B Phantom</a> for passive scanning of jet-engine emissions, but it possessed limited capabilities and was eliminated on F-4Ds and later models.
In 1956, TI began research on <a href="infrared">infrared</a> technology that led to several line scanner contracts and with the addition of a second scan mirror the invention of the first <a href="forward%20looking%20infrared">forward looking infrared</a> (FLIR) in 1963 with production beginning in 1966. In 1972, TI invented the common module FLIR concept, greatly reducing cost and allowing reuse of common components.
TI went on to produce side-looking radar systems, the first <a href="terrain%20following%20radar">terrain-following radar</a> and surveillance radar systems for both the military and FAA. TI demonstrated the first solid-state radar called Molecular Electronics for Radar Applications. In 1976, TI developed a <a href="microwave%20landing%20system">microwave landing system</a> prototype. In 1984, TI developed the first <a href="inverse%20synthetic%20aperture%20radar">inverse synthetic aperture radar</a>. The first single-chip <a href="gallium%20arsenide">gallium arsenide</a> radar module was developed. In 1991, the military microwave integrated circuit program was initiated a joint effort with Raytheon.
In 1961, TI won the guidance and control system contract for the defense suppression <a href="AGM-45%20Shrike">AGM-45 Shrike</a> <a href="antiradiation%20missile">antiradiation missile</a>. This led later to the prime on the <a href="AGM-88%20HARM">high-speed antiradiation missile</a> (AGM-88 HARM) development contract in 1974 and production in 1981.
In 1964, TI began development of the first laser guidance system for <a href="precision-guided%20munition">precision-guided munition</a>s, leading to the <a href="Paveway">Paveway</a> series of <a href="laser-guided%20bomb">laser-guided bomb</a>s (LGBs). The first LGB was the <a href="BOLT-117">BOLT-117</a>.
In 1969, TI won the Harpoon (missile) Seeker contract. In 1986, TI won the Army <a href="FGM-148%20Javelin">FGM-148 Javelin</a> <a href="fire-and-forget">fire-and-forget</a> man portable antitank guided missile in a joint venture with <a href="Martin%20Marietta">Martin Marietta</a>. In 1991, TI was awarded the contract for the <a href="AGM-154%20Joint%20Standoff%20Weapon">AGM-154 Joint Standoff Weapon</a>.
Because of TI's research and development of military temperature-range silicon transistors and integrated circuits (ICs), TI won contracts for the first IC-based computer for the U.S. Air Force in 1961 (molecular electronic computer) and for ICs for the Minuteman Missile the following year. In 1968, TI developed the data systems for <a href="Mariner%20Program">Mariner Program</a>. In 1991 TI won the F-22 Radar and Computer development contract.
As the defense industry consolidated, TI sold its defense business to <a href="Raytheon">Raytheon</a> in 1997 for $2.95 billion. The Department of Justice required that Raytheon divest the TI <a href="Monolithic%20Microwave%20Integrated%20Circuit">Monolithic Microwave Integrated Circuit</a> (MMIC) operations after closing the transaction. The TI MMIC business accounted for less than $40 million in 1996 revenues, or roughly 2% of the $1.8 billion in total TI defense revenues, and was sold to <a href="TriQuint%20Semiconductor">TriQuint Semiconductor</a>, Inc. Raytheon retained its own existing <a href="MMIC">MMIC</a> capabilities and has the right to license TI's MMIC technology for use in future product applications from TriQuint.
Shortly after Raytheon acquired TI DSEG, Raytheon then acquired <a href="Hughes%20Aircraft">Hughes Aircraft</a> from <a href="General%20Motors">General Motors</a>. Raytheon then owned TI's <a href="mercury%20cadmium%20telluride">mercury cadmium telluride</a> detector business and <a href="infrared">infrared</a> (IR) systems group. In California, it also had Hughes infrared detector and an IR systems business. When again the US government forced Raytheon to divest itself of a duplicate capability, the company kept the TI IR systems business and the Hughes detector business. As a result of these acquisitions, these former arch rivals of TI systems and Hughes detectors work together.
Immediately after acquisition, DSEG was known as Raytheon TI Systems (RTIS). It is now fully integrated into Raytheon and this designation no longer exists.
Artificial intelligence.
TI was active in the area of <a href="artificial%20intelligence">artificial intelligence</a> in the 1980s. In addition to ongoing developments in speech and signal processing and recognition, it developed and sold the <a href="TI%20Explorer">Explorer</a> computer family of <a href="Lisp%20machine">Lisp machine</a>s. For the Explorer, a special 32-bit Lisp microprocessor was developed, which was used in the Explorer II and the TI MicroExplorer (a Lisp Machine on a <a href="NuBus">NuBus</a> board for the Apple <a href="Macintosh">Macintosh</a>). AI application software developed by TI for the Explorer included the gate assignment system for United Airlines, <a href="http%3A//articles.latimes.com/1989-11-07/business/fi-1112_1_expert-system">described as</a> "an artificial intelligence program that captures the combined experience and knowledge of a half-dozen United operations experts." In software for the PC, they introduced "Personal Consultant", a rule-based <a href="expert%20system">expert system</a> development tool and runtime engine, followed by "Personal Consultant Plus" written in the Lisp-like language from MIT known as <a href="Scheme%20%28programming%20language%29">Scheme</a>, and the natural language menu system NLMenu.
Sensors and controls.
TI was a major <a href="Original%20equipment%20manufacturer">original-equipment manufacturer</a> of <a href="sensor">sensor</a>, control, protection, and <a href="RFID">RFID</a> products for the automotive, appliance, aircraft, and other industries. The Sensors & Controls division was headquartered in <a href="Attleboro%2C%20Massachusetts">Attleboro, Massachusetts</a>.
By the mid-1980s, industrial computers known as PLC's (programmable logic controllers) were separated from Sensors & Controls as the Industrial Systems Division, which was sold in the late 1980s to Siemens.
In 2006, <a href="Bain%20Capital%20LLC">Bain Capital LLC</a>, a private equity firm, purchased the Sensors & Controls division for $3.0 billion in cash. The RFID portion of the division remained part of TI, transferring to the Application Specific Products business unit of the Semiconductor division, with the newly formed independent company based in Attleboro taking the name Sensata Technologies.
Software.
In 1997, TI sold its software division, along with its main products such as the <a href="CA%20Gen">CA Gen</a>, to <a href="Sterling%20Software">Sterling Software</a>, which is now part of <a href="Computer%20Associates">Computer Associates</a>. However, TI still owns small pieces of software, such as the software for calculators such as the <a href="TI%20Interactive%21">TI Interactive!</a>. TI also creates a significant amount of target software for its digital signal processors, along with host-based tools for creating DSP applications.
TI.com.
In 2000, Texas Instruments first implemented an e-commerce platform on TI.com as a way to sell its Code Composer Studio™ software tool directly to customers. With TI.com, purchase managers and design engineers have access to TI products that are immediately available for shipping. The platform has grown to include tens of thousands of TI analog and embedded processing products. In 2020, TI added several features, including full and custom quantity reels, multiple payment options, lines of credit, and flat-rate shipping.
Restatement.
On August 6, 1999, TI announced the restatement of its results for parts of 1998 and the first quarter of 1999 after a review by the <a href="Securities%20and%20Exchange%20Commission">Securities and Exchange Commission</a> over the timing of charges for a plant closing and writedown.
Finances.
For the fiscal year 2017, Texas Instruments reported earnings of US$3.682 billion, with an annual revenue of US$14.961 billion, an increase of 11.9% over the previous fiscal cycle. TI shares traded at over $82 per share, and its market capitalization was valued at over US$88.0 billion in October 2018. As of 2018, TI ranked 192nd on the <a href="Fortune%20500">Fortune 500</a> list of the largest United States corporations by revenue.
Divisions.
Today, TI is made up of four divisions: <a href="analog%20electronics">analog products</a>, <a href="embedded%20processor">embedded processor</a>s, <a href="digital%20light%20processing">digital light processing</a>, and <a href="educational%20technology">educational technology</a>.
As of January 2021, the industrial market accounts for 41 percent of the company's annual revenue while the automotive market accounts f21 percent.
Other businesses.
TI's remaining businesses consisting of DLP products (primarily used in projectors to create high-definition images), calculators and certain custom semiconductors known as application-specific integrated circuits.
DLP Products.
DLP is a trademark under which Texas Instruments sells technology regarding TVs, video projectors, and <a href="digital%20cinema">digital cinema</a>. On February 2, 2000, Philippe Binant, technical manager of Digital Cinema Project at <a href="Gaumont%20Film%20Company">Gaumont</a> in France, realized the first digital cinema projection in Europe with the DLP CINEMA technology developed by TI. DLP technology enables a diverse range of display and advanced light control applications spanning industrial, enterprise, automotive, and consumer market segments.
The ASICs business develops more complex integrated-circuit solutions for clients on a custom basis.
Educational technology.
TI has produced educational toys for children, including the <a href="Little%20Professor">Little Professor</a> in 1976 and <a href="Dataman">Dataman</a> in 1977.
TI produces a range of calculators, with the <a href="TI-30">TI-30</a> being one of the most popular early <a href="calculator">calculator</a>s. TI has also developed a line of <a href="graphing%20calculator">graphing calculator</a>s, the first being the <a href="TI-81">TI-81</a>, and most popular being the <a href="TI-83%20Plus">TI-83 Plus</a> (with the <a href="TI-84%20Plus">TI-84 Plus</a> being an updated equivalent).
Many TI calculators are still sold without graphing capabilities. The TI-30 has been replaced by the <a href="TI-30">TI-30X IIS</a>. Also, some financial calculators are for sale on the TI website.
In 2007, TI released the <a href="TI-Nspire">TI-Nspire</a> family of calculators and computer software that has similar capabilities to the calculators.
Less than 3% of Texas Instruments’ overall revenue comes from calculators, part of the $1.43 billion revenue in the "Other" section in the company's 2018 annual report. Nevertheless, the calculators are a lucrative product. For example, estimates have a $15 to $20 cost to produce TI-84 Plus which likely has a profit margin of at least 50%.
Throughout the 1980s, Texas Instruments worked closely with National Council of Teachers of Mathematics (NCTM) to develop a calculator to become the educational standard. In 1986, Connecticut School Board became the first to require a graphing calculator on state-mandated exams. Chicago Public Schools gave a free calculator to every student, beginning in the fourth grade, in 1988. New York required the calculator in 1992 for its Regents exams after first allowing it the previous year. The College Board required calculators on the Advanced Placement tests in 1993 and allowed calculators on the SAT a year later. Texas Instruments provides free services to the College Board, which administers AP tests and the SAT, and also has a group called Teachers Teaching for Technology (T3), which educates teachers on how to use its calculators.
TI calculator community.
In the 1990s, with the advent of TI's graphing calculator series, programming became popular among some students. The TI-8x series of calculators (beginning with the TI-81) came with a built-in <a href="BASIC">BASIC</a> interpreter, through which simple programs could be created. The <a href="TI-85">TI-85</a> was the first TI calculator to allow <a href="assembly%20language">assembly</a> programming (via a shell called "ZShell"), and the TI-83 was the first in the series to receive native assembly.
Around the same time that these programs were first being written, personal <a href="web%20page">web page</a>s were becoming popular (through services such as <a href="Angelfire">Angelfire</a> and <a href="GeoCities">GeoCities</a>), and programmers began creating websites to host their work, along with tutorials and other calculator-relevant information. This led to the formation of TI calculator <a href="webrings">webrings</a> and eventually a few large communities, including the now-defunct TI-Files and still-active ticalc.org.
The TI community reached the height of its popularity in the early 2000s, with new websites and programming groups being started almost daily. In fact, the aforementioned community sites were exploding with activity, with close to 100 programs being uploaded daily by users of the sites. Also, a competition existed between both sites to be the top site in the community, which helped increase interest and activity in the community.
One of the common unifying forces that has united the community over the years has been the rather contentious relationship with TI regarding control over its graphing calculators. TI graphing calculators generally fall into two distinct groups—those powered by the <a href="Zilog%20Z80">Zilog Z80</a> and those running on the <a href="Motorola%2068000">Motorola 68000</a> series. Both lines of calculators are locked by TI with checks in the hardware and through the signing of software to disable use of custom flash applications and operating systems.
However, users employed the <a href="general%20number%20field%20sieve">general number field sieve</a> to find the keys and publish them in 2009. TI responded by sending invalid <a href="DMCA">DMCA</a> <a href="takedown%20notice">takedown notice</a>s, causing the <a href="Texas%20Instruments%20signing%20key%20controversy">Texas Instruments signing key controversy</a>. Enthusiasts had already been creating their own operating systems before the finding of the keys, which could be installed with other methods.
Competitors.
TI has the largest market share in the analog semiconductor industry, which has an estimated <a href="total%20addressable%20market">total addressable market</a> exceeding US$37 billion.
Acquisitions.
National Semiconductor acquisition.
On April 4, 2011, Texas Instruments announced that it had agreed to buy <a href="National%20Semiconductor">National Semiconductor</a> for $6.5 billion in cash. TI paid $25 per share of National Semiconductor stock, which was an 80% premium over the share price of $14.07 as of April 4, 2011 close. The deal made TI the world's largest maker of analog technology components.
The companies formally merged on September 23, 2011.
